job_title: Partnership Engagement Executive in Manchester, England
pros: Great atmosphere on the sales floor and within the teams. Everybody gets on. If you want to work hard, the rewards are there. Management are always open to discuss your point of view and will always look to help if you have a problem in your personal life. They are always looking at improving team morale with work days and nights out. Couldn't fault it.
cons: None. As long as you are willing to work for the rewards.

pros: Salary was ok, and central location
cons: Management were yes men to the senior managers, and didn't have the acks of the staff.

pros: Good team work and colleagues
cons: Targets unrealistic and quite stressful

pros:
Good working environment
Good learning experience
cons: Some staff are abrupt or rude

job_title: Tutor in Warrington, North West England, England
pros: Large employer under a college
cons: Now closed no longer open

pros:
-You get to meet some great people (especially those who are not up the managers arses all the time!)
-Location was good.
cons:
-Corrupt, vindictive managers, who work alongside two-faced members of staff below them to target innocent, vulnerable individuals in their own team and bully them out of a job. 
-Put a complaint in, question management and you’ll be bullied, targeted by management. HR are just as corrupt and fail to follow through complaints and aggrievances correctly.
-Lack of support from management, who are too busy on their phones updating their social media rather than doing any actual work; rather they delegate work and take credit for the work done. 
-Credit is given to those who do no actual work and sit around doing nothing (apart from eating and scoffing their faces) 
-Genuine, sincere staff are treated poorly. If you’re into snitching and making up lies to management about your fellow colleagues then your face fits perfectly in this company and you’ll be protected by management.

pros:
Excellent personal and professional development opportunities, if you choose to pester your line manager to be able complete them.
When I first started the culture was excellent, shame that went down the drain.
cons:
No progression prospects
Local management is poor
'Jobs for the boys' culture
Paperwork for paperwork's sake
Local management protect and promote their 'friends'
Lack of meaningful communication
Expect a lot of hours to be worked, it's very difficult to get your time owed back.
Very difficult to get any bonus, the criteria is impossible to attain.
Few resources available and what was available was poor quality.

pros: Prior to being made redundant I loved my job, I enjoyed seeing young people achieving their qualifications and knowing that I was part of that.  I enjoyed the contact with the people and the customer service side of my role.
cons:
Unfortunately I have nothing good to say about Intraining, they took over the company I was working for and after about a year stripped it off all the assets and made all office staff redundant.  They had a poor HR process and had no intention of listening to the ideas put forward from staff to change the working practices.

Prior to this they had some very tedious processes that meant jumping through a lot of hoops in order to get suppliers paid.

pros:
At site and operations level, management was great. 

Largely a good team spirit. The sites and quality team genuinely cares about customers and learners. Very supportive OST.

Some opportunities to progress, until restructures started.
cons:
Qualification based pay scale, while somewhat objective, led to low capability staff earning more than competent team members.

Poor leadership at higher levels. No communication of process changes leading to countless hours rectifying others mistakes.

Restructures becoming regular.

pros: Round the corner from city centre
cons: Bully environment from manager which HR supported when you complained.   You were expected to be loyal to the company but the company got rid of you with no remorse.  No support from managers especially when they set too targets.

pros: Errrmmm... give me a minute...
cons:
A recent round of widescale redundancies has left this company a busted flush.

Instead of streamlining processes and embedding systems first, Directors have opted for the big bang approach and simply slashed staff numbers (along with morale) to unsustainable levels. A short sighted financial win with far reaching consequences for operational performance. This misguided strategy has seen an exodus of experienced, knowledgeable staff and heaped misery on an already demoralised workforce. The resulting knowledge drain has forced the business to backfill vacancies with interim and temporary staff in a desperate attempt to shore up the depleted infrastructure. A shameful spending spree has seen an endless parade of consultants brought in to pick over the wreckage and support clearly overwhelmed Directors.

Staff at risk of redundancy are invited to reapply for roles with impossibly high workloads to cover staff losses elsewhere and some have been asked to sign new contracts with increased working hours and reduced leave. Maybe this explains the embarrassingly low levels of staff willing to reapply. Surprised? Really?

One or two of the new influx of Directors arrive with an air of arrogance treating existing employees with disdain. Support staff are not responsible for declining success rates and work exceptionally hard to provide a quality service. Many have seen your 'new' ideas tried in the past and can no doubt provide valuable insight into why they didn't work. Please note; Intraining and Rathbone are NOT colleges. They are complex organisational structures delivering a wide range of contracts across England, Scotland and Wales against multiple UKPRNs. They work with some of the most challenging learners imaginable so don't expect what previously worked for you in the FE sector to work here.

If you're looking to work for a training provider with poor OFSTED ratings, dire financial woes, ineffective leadership, a chaotic management style and a severley depleted workforce then you've found it. Good luck... just don't say you weren't warned.

review_title: Good middle management but high targets
pros: Some good bosses but targets very high and difficult to consistently achieve
cons: Limited career progression training and qualifications you leave with the same skill set you came in with. Loss of contracts imminent

review_title: Best company I have worked for

+ Good customer focus
+ Encourage staff to act with integrity
+ Fair pay
+ Good management at lower levels
+ High but fair workload
cons:
+ Some of the higher management team were questionable
+ Poor communication (but were working on this at time of leaving.

review_title: Good employer, shame it was temporary.
pros: Fantastic team to work with, great job with opportunity to meet varied & interesting customers. Good staff development.
cons: Managers under a lot of stress, which seeps down onto employees shoulders, but where doesn't that happen! Nothing major to moan about.

pros: No benefits for working here
cons:
Punish the unemployed to line their own pockets with the taxpayers money.
Fraudelent activity with tutors sitting exams for students and giving answers.
Students put on courses well below their level to enable the compant to put them through multiple courses and pocket more funding.
A waste of governments money.
No way can this be seen to be a credible educational organisation
